title: Relative problem paths don't take `cwd` into account

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/2518
by @galgalesh 
--------------------------------------------------------

**Type: LanguageService**
<!----- Input information below ----->

<!--
**Please review existing issues and our documentation at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools/tree/master/Documentation prior to filing an issue.**
-->

**Describe the bug**
- OS and Version: Ubuntu 18.04
- VS Code Version:  1.27.1 5944e81f3c46a3938a82c701f96d7a59b074cfdc x64
- C/C++ Extension Version: 0.18.1
- Other extensions you installed (and if the issue persists after disabling them):
- A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

The problemMatcher doesn't take the `cwd` of a task into account when resolving relative paths.

**To Reproduce**
<!-- Steps to reproduce the behavior: -->
<!-- *The most actionable issue reports include a code sample including configuration files such as c_cpp_properties.json* -->

Create a task and set the `cwd` of that task to a different path.

**Expected behavior**

The problemMatcher resolves relative paths as relative to `cwd`. If you set the `cwd` of a task, relative paths will most likely be relative to the `cwd`, not to the workspaceFolder.

**Behavior I get**

The problemMatcher resolves relative paths as relative to `workspaceFolder`

Following is the `tasks.json` for such a task. The line starting with ` "fileLocation"` shouldn't be neccisary.

```
        {
            "label": "build adfgxx",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "ninja",
            "args": [
            ],
            "group": {
                "kind": "build",
                "isDefault": true
            },
            "problemMatcher": {
                "base": "$gcc",
                // The next line shouldn't be needed since it is the same value as `cwd`
                "fileLocation" : ["relative", "${workspaceFolder}/builddir"]
            },
            "options": {
                "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}/builddir",
            }
        }
```


**Additional context**
<!--
*Call Stacks: For bugs like crashes, deadlocks, infinite loops, etc. that we are not able to repro and for which the call stack may be useful, please attach a debugger and/or create a dmp and provide the call stacks. Starting with 0.17.3, Windows binaries have symbols available in VS Code by setting your "symbolSearchPath" to "http://msdl.microsoft.com/download/symbols".*
Add any other context about the problem here including log messages in your Output window ("C_Cpp.loggingLevel": "Debug" in settings.json).
-->

title: [Extension API] Expose Viewport's Horizontal Range?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
As I understand it, only the vertical range of the viewport can be obtained via `TextEditor.visibleRanges`.  It would be great if there is a way to get the horizontal range as well. 

Knowing the horizontal range would allow me to, after revealing other ranges in the editor, restore the viewport to its original state. At present I am only able to do that vertically. 

I would essentially like to mimic the behavior that `Go to Line...` functionality does when `Escape` is pressed and the viewport's initial state is restored.

title: NPM extension: Support relative glob patterns
body: see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/48698#issuecomment-422194382

title: Settings: Utilize Button for all 'Edit settings.json' link
body:
@roblourens 

While keyboarding through the settings I think it might look better to utilize a button instead of a link.
The Link sort of dangles a bit.  Additionally there are two functional issues:
- The link gets read with the extra hyperlink baggage
- Separately , for any of these non-typical input elements , having the User Land on a button which also uses described by will be more obvious for accessibility users.
- For elements like 'Files Exclude' , starting on the Add button would also be a little bit more obvious than the link in the description.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25272315/45729193-6b562c00-bb99-11e8-9136-e70789e72fbb.png)

title: SelectBox: Update ctor, organize for new options eg Settings requirements

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
SelectBox additions over time, especially new requirements in the settings editor (extended descriptions, labels) has resulted in a non optimal ctor and widget interface.  Needs some re- factoring.

- Consolidate selectOptionEntry options into new option interface
- Support option details/aria labels in both ctor and updated setOptions
- Improve details provider, use interface not callback
- Update SelectBox clients as necessary

title: Add font aliasing settings to other platforms than mac
body: Currently, fonts designed to be used aliased are anti-aliased on Linux and Windows. It would be very useful to have an option to disable font AA for these platforms.

milestone.title: Backlog

body: Issue Type: Feature Request Just like the launch.json supports the ability to host the application, i would like to be able to host my tasks in an external console window. Some console workloads i have are to heavy for xTerm.js and the ability to accidentally kill one of those processes when killing terminal processes with the trash can button is a little bit annoying. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.28.0-insider (cd9d71a31f731baf17330a84448c3efdeabc873f, 2018-09-17T05:20:06.620Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

title: feature request: "locking" a text buffer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Summary:
Feature Idea: allow to specify a buffer's (start, end) so that  text operations work on a specific "locked" text buffer

Description:
I think it's a good idea: allow to lock a certain text region or buffer, so when I do search replace and other operations like renaming, or really any of the many extensions, the operations will work on only that part, leaving the rest of the file unchanged.
An example is a long file, where we have a short text to replace, but the replace value changes according to context. for example in a long file that has code for an entire namespace, I am adding a self variable to all the functions, yet the type changes frequently (other classes are being defined). So I would like operations to have an effect only in that delimited area.

it's like extending the idea of "selection". the find widget can work only within the selection. I would like all operations to be restricted, when I specify such a region. 

What do you think?

PS: vscode is awesome. it's my programming editor of choice.

title: Documentation confusion with ExtensionContext.logPath
body: I was working on adding the new `logPath` functionality to an extension of mine, but the documentation was very confusing, and I'm not able to use it for my purpose. Bases on the current wording, it seemed like each extension would get a unique directory, and this directory would be the same across VS Code invocations. However, through testing, I am getting a unique directory per time VS Code is opened. Can this be cleared up in the documentation? It makes a major difference in the usefulness of the API.

title: Change bracket match functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Matching brackets have always bothered me in Visual Studio Code and I finally realized what it is: they are shown when inside the brackets **in addition to** being shown when outside of the brackets. This gives an unfavorable visual effect for two reasons: 1. It's not consistent. Your cursor position being on the left or right of a bracket set, will have different results depending on if brackets are nested. 2. More importantly, it's distracting when you **a)** click inside of empty parens **b)** update an argument inside of parens (screenshot below). Preferably, matching brackets would only show when the cursor is outside of those matching brackets. This reduces unnecessary distractions and also makes nested brackets more consistent. For reference, this is the default behavior in WebStorm — I'm not sure how other editors handle it. This could be a settings option, but my guess is that most would actually prefer it as the default if shown the difference.

title: [folding] editor.showFoldingControls: never

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
`editor.showFoldingControls` only allows for "always" and "mouseover". It would be nice if we could disable it entirely.

The only way to remove the controls (and save space in the editor) is to set `"editor.folding": false`. However, this will also disable the keyboard shortcuts for folding.

Preferably, we could disable the UI controls (saving space in the editor by decreasing the gutter width), while still being able to use the keyboard shortcuts.

UI controls are not necessary for simple folding (fold imports, fold a method, etc.).

body: Issue Type: Feature Request So currently it works fine, if I open a new `` an close tag is auto done. However: 1) there are instances where, I need to wrap a sentence or word with a `` or `""`. Would have loved to have a feature, where I can make the selection and then if I type in a or a ", it auto closes at the end of the selection. 2) currently, if the `` I opened is touching to an existing content/word. The close ` `overwrites/replaces the word, which the opening `` was touching. I know that the particular configurations of my key bindings can be improved and I don't know what `case State.Details` represents. Feedback and help appreciated here!

title: VS Code ignores any unknown command line options instead of showing an error

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. --> 
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.27.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.17134.285 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run `code --foo bar`
2. VS Code launches successfully.

I'd expect giving unknown options to error out so as to catch typos, unsupported options, and what not. To do this we probably need to use the `unknown` option for the minimist parser at [src/vs/platform/environment/node/argv.ts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/dbeeecbaedaf236ccb423685a17b95ee5476fc97/src/vs/platform/environment/node/argv.ts#L16). I guess it should print an error and `process.exit(2)`.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: autoClosingPairs in language-configuration.json doesn't allow multiple entries that use quotes.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'm looking for a way to support autoClosingPair of:

`' ' `, `" "`, `@' '@`, and `@" "@`

However, when I add, for example:

`["@'","'@"]` to the `language-configuration.json` it doesn't work and still autocloses just ` ' ` so it looks like `@''`.

If I remove [this entry](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/powershell/language-configuration.json#L16) from the autoClosingPairs, then `@'` closes properly to become `@''@`. But then `'` no longer completes.

Is there a way to do what I'm trying to do?

body:

Issue Type: Polish
Continuation of #58445 except to meet the guidelines.

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In every sidebar view, the margin of searchboxes is off. In the majority of cases, the right side of the input has less space than the left side. Additionally (and most apparent in the Extensions view), bottom margin is also too small compared to the rest of the spacing. The solution would simply be to increase the margin on the right-hand side of searchboxes by about 5px? And on the bottom about the same.

Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-pull-request-github/issues/295

It would be great if there was an option for a secondary button style so that views with multiple buttons could differentiate the primary vs secondary. Below is a webview example that has multiple buttons:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35271042/45335156-e339ac00-b532-11e8-902e-22d234219162.png)

It would be great if we could get the following:
- button.secondary.background
- button.secondary.foreground
- button.secondary.hoverBackground

title: Use short description from MDN for better CSS completion details

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
MDN team is working on making short description for CSS properties available: https://github.com/mdn/data/issues/261. We could use those to replace the ones we have in our legacy database. We are already doing so for the new CSS properties that our legacy database do not contain. See: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-css-languageservice/blob/master/build/mdn/mdn-documentation.js

Similar to using compatibility data from MDN, we'll use the description from MDN too.

![](https://code.visualstudio.com/assets/updates/1_25/css-justify-items.png)

One thing that has not been decided is if there should be a link at the end of completion details that point to the relevant MDN article. The motivation is that people might find it useful when they want to "read more" about a specific CSS property. It is also an attribution to MDN as we are using their data.

The concern is some people might find that it adds noise to the completion item.

title: Menu bar toggling is inconsistent with the rest of Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'm splitting out some [previously reported issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35010#issuecomment-339695865) since they weren't resolved with the fix to the original issue.

There are a couple of quirks with the keybinding for toggling the menu bar that don't match other Windows applications and cause workflow annoyances. These both occur when `window.menuBarVisibility` is set to `toggle`.

1. Hold Ctrl, press and release Alt, notice the menu bar is toggled.
Expected: the menu bar is not toggled.
I've tested with various other applications on Windows including Notepad, Paint, and Firefox. None of them do this.

2. Press and release Alt, press escape, notice the menu bar does not get hidden.
Expected: the menu bar should be hidden.
I tested with Firefox and Visual Studio 2015 (using https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=MatthewJohnsonMSFT.HideMainMenu) and both will hide the menu bar when escape is pressed.

Issue 1 is a daily annoyance for me, as it seems to happen very frequently when I jump between editor groups.

Also, the new custom title bar doesn't have these issues and it feels like the menu bars should be consistent with each other and with the rest of the Windows experience.
